The "Connecticut Old State House Bicentennial Commemorative Coin Act" recognizes the historical significance of the Old State House in Hartford, Connecticut, linking it to the city, state, and country's history. The site is where the Colony of Connecticut was founded, and where key Revolutionary War strategies were planned. The Old State House, designed by Charles Bulfinch, is a notable example of 18th-century architecture and has been designated a Registered National Landmark. The Old State House in Hartford, Connecticut, operated as a museum and public meeting place, underwent extensive renovations in 1992 to expand its services. The new Old State House will feature a Museum of Connecticut History, a market on Main Street, and a Peace Park. It will be rededicated on its 200th birthday in May 1996, becoming a focal point for the region. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue up to 700,000 one dollar silver coins in commemoration of the bicentennial of the Old State House in Hartford, Connecticut. The coins will weigh 26.73 grams, have a diameter of 1.500 inches, and contain 90 percent silver and 10 percent copper. They will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The silver for minting the coins will be obtained from stockpiles established under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. SEC. 4. DESIGN OF COINS. The design of the coins minted under this Act shall be emblematic of the Old State House in Hartford, Connecticut, and the United States. Each coin will feature a value designation, the years "1796-1996", and inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with various organizations. Each coin will feature a value designation, the years "1796-1996", and inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with various organizations. The design will be reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee and the Commission of Fine Arts. SEC. 5 of the Act specifies that coins will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities from a single mint facility during 1996. The Secretary will sell coins at a price including face value, surcharge, and cost of production. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will receive a reasonable discount. A $10 surcharge per coin will be included in all sales. SEC. 7. GENERAL WAIVER OF PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS. No procurement laws apply to goods and services needed for this Act, except for equal employment opportunity laws. SEC. 8. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. The Secretary shall promptly pay surcharges from coin sales to the Old State House Association for construction, education, and maintenance purposes. The Comptroller General of the United States has the right to audit the financial records. The Comptroller General of the United States has the right to examine financial records related to expenditures of amounts paid to the Old State House Association. SEC. 9. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. The Secretary must ensure minting coins won't cost the government. Payment for coins requires full payment, security, or a guarantee from a depository institution.
